title: Theories of Global Political Economy
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course provides an introduction to broad themes, key concepts, and major theories used to understand the global political economy, and how national political-economies fit into the global system. In the first half, we will cover a bit of methodology and the philosophy of science of political economy, the history of the global political-economic system, contemporary controversies, and possible futures. In the second half, we will cover the major theories that scholars have constructed to make sense of the global political economy, including economic nationalism or realism, liberalism, and critical theories. Having prior knowledge of international relations scholarship or economics will help, but is not strictly necessary. The aim of this course is to provide an intellectual foundation for understanding how the world system operates, and for further, more specialized studies in the many areas that GPE covers.
outcome: • Substantive Knowledge:   The “big picture” of what Global Political Economy covers as an academic discipline: interactions between politics and economics, the history and development of political-economic systems, and understanding the contemporary world system.   Students should be conversant with the essential themes, concepts, and terms employed in the study of global political economy.   Familiarity with the major theories that have been constructed to make sense of the global political economy, where they differ and where they overlap, and their strengths and weaknesses. • Critical Analysis:   Students should be able to identify the central thesis of books or articles, understand how the authors develop and defend it, and critically evaluate the author’s thesis, evidence, and logic.   Students should be able to assess the strength and weaknesses of theories/arguments in GPE and engage in critical discussions and debates.
syllabus: 1. Methodology and the philosophy of science of political economy Ontology, epistemology, scientific realism, the artificial divide between politics and economics  2. The history of the global political economy Deep history, history of economic development, history of the global financial and economic systems  3. Contemporary problems Financialization, financial reform nationally and internationally  4. The future of political economies Money and its function in political economy  5. Theories through which to understand the complex system Economic nationalism/realism, liberalism, critical theories

title: Methodology in Social Sciences
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course gives emphasis on the application of methodological principles and data analysis techniques in designing and conducting research in Social Sciences, with an objective of enabling students to investigate local, regional or global issues with a design-based approach of social enquiry. Course contents include basic concepts in research designs, data collection strategies and data analysis methods. Both quantitative and qualitative approaches will be discussed to analyze topics in global political economy.

Identify and formulate research questions of a research proposal; 3. Select and collect a body of academic literature which is relevant to the research questions; 4. Describe and explain relationships between the selected independent and dependent variables; 5. Apply research design relevant to the research questions;  6. Compare and contrast the strength and weakness of each method; 7. Produce an empirical research proposal; 8. Identify possible societal, political, economic and organizational dynamics that would affect  research processes; 11. Follow codes of ethics while designing and implementing the research proposal.

title: International Financial and Trade Policy: From Bretton Woods to G20/Doha
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course examines the nature, evolution and particularly the ramifications of the Bretton Woods system and institutions, particularly for companies and other organizations operating in Asia. Global financial institutions and especially international trade and investment, their roles and issues, will be explored. This will include recognizing and understanding the characteristics and challenges of trade and investment across borders, and managing the associated opportunities and threats, illustrated by case examples. The course will begin with an overview of the Bretton Woods system, its rise and fall, and subsequent efforts to manage the global economy. It will discuss the implications of the rules and politics of finance, trade and investment, and issues like globalization, protectionism and the role of foreign direct investment. The focus will be on how international trade and finance rules and particularly policies actually work and don't work for companies and other organizations operating in Asia, with special attention paid to recent developments like the Asia Infrastructure Development Bank, new bilateral and multilateral economic agreements and the evolving role of the G-20.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1) Acquire knowledge of the post – war economic and financial system, and current developments and trends occurring;  2) Develop a deeper understanding regarding the effects of shifts and changes in International Trade on International Relations and domestic politics; and 3) Analyze the strengths and weaknesses of the current system.

title: International Investment Policy: Economic and Business Perspectives
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course consists of two closely interrelated and complementary parts. The aim of the economic part is to describe and explain the origins, forms, and consequences of international investment. Both foreign direct investment (FDI) and international portfolio investment are highlighted, but greater emphasis is placed on the former. The role played by governments and international institutions is accorded considerable attention. The aim of the business part is to describe and explain in an elaborate fashion the role played by multinational/transnational enterprises (MNEs/TNEs), the key players in global business arena, in the world economy. The forces shaping this role and MNEs responses—strategic, tactical, and operational—are highlighted. Regulatory matters are accorded considerable attention.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  a. To gain insight into the economic nature, sources, dynamics and impacts of FDI; b. To possess an awareness of the factors impinging on public policies towards FDI and their effectiveness;  c. To gain insight into the nature of MNEs, their role in the global economy, their structures, their strategies, and their operations; d. To obtain an appreciation of their multiple impacts, both favourable and unfavourable, on host economies; e. To understand their complex and evolving relationships with governments and other regulatory agencies.

title: Currency War – Past, Present and Future
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: The Currency War that erupted in 2010 has weaken the financial foundation of the world’s advanced economies and eroded the currency functions of the three global currencies (the USD, Euro and Japanese yen), or G3 currencies. This has given the Chinese renminbi a window of opportunity to rise and challenge the global dominance of the G3 currencies. This is a structural change that will shake up the global political economy and monetary system in the decades to come by adding a new player – China – to the future currency war. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping is pushing through structural reforms to chase his "Chinese Dream" when the global powers are repositioning to accommodate the renminbi in the global system. The course will encompass the past, present and future aspects of the currency war by integrating China’s development in the global currency war environment. It will prepare students for understanding the coming changes in Mainland China and how they will affect the global monetary system and political economy. The course will start with some basic economic concepts that are needed to understand the economics part of the course. It will use the currency war development to explain the rise of the renminbi, the political and economic challenges behind the opening up of China and the evolution of China's policy and financial development in shaping the future of the world economy.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1) understand the development of the currency war and its impact on the global system;  2) understand the rising importance of China from a currency perspective in the context of the currency war;  3) learn about the future development of China’s political and financial development in preparation for accommodating the new China in the business, investment and academic sectors.
syllabus: The lectures will cover the following topics: • Theoretical concepts needed to understand and analyse the world’s currency war • The origin of currency war and economic/policy lessons learnt from experience • Development of the currency war and the renminbi’s mega trend • Rotational currency depreciation, an alternative definition of currency war • Hong Kong and China in currency war  • The rise of the renminbi to challenge the G3 currencies  • Structural drivers that are changing the dynamics behind the G3 currencies and the renminbi  • Erosion of the financial prowess of the advance economies by the currency war and a window of opportunity for the rise of the renminbi • Currency war prompts renminbi reform • The advent of the “Impossible Trinity” as the renminbi rises and as China’s capital account opens up • The political reality and challenges for China to manage the rise of its currency to become a global currency in the currency war environment • Renminbi internationalisation, progress, challenges, and the next step in the context of the currency war • China’s Belt and Road initiative and renminbi internationalisation  • Myths, hypes and truth of the Belt and Road initiative • The future of the renminbi (what will make it a global currency?)

title: Global Energy Markets
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: Energy drives the modern world. The availability of cheap and plentiful energy such as fossil fuels and nuclear energy has transformed every aspect of human civilization. Electricity and petroleum products such as gasoline, diesel, natural gas, and petrochemical products are essential to the well-functioning of a world economy, and its availability key to lifting a country out of poverty. News headlines are often dominated by energy issues which include energy shortages and disruptions, spiking gasoline and diesel prices at the pump, acute electricity generation crisis in many developed countries, and unaffordable energy prices for developing countries, all with highly relevant political and economic consequences. Global energy instability is likely to be a paramount political issue of our time in the foreseeable future. This course aims to provide a rigorous and systemic overview and understanding of global energy markets, one of the most complex and capital-intensive economic systems in the world. This course teaches the basic language of energy and its measurements; supply/demand balance and what it means; how the various energy markets work and their interconnectedness; issues driving energy market trends and disruptions; and the critical and emerging issues that will impact these markets. This course offers a balanced and realistic understanding of energy issues, primarily with fact and data-based information and insights, aided by the introduction of powerful frameworks to help illuminate these topics and challenge conventional wisdom or myths. The course aims to enlighten understanding and discussion of energy market issues that will continue to dominate news headlines. Students should have an open mind and be creative. Active participation in class discussion is highly encouraged. Never hesitate to interrupt the instructor in the classroom. The instructor welcomes questions and appreciates challenges. The hope is that students will have fun in taking the course and get more interested in the topics after one semester.
outcome: Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to acquire an informed and fact-based view of the global world energy economy, which includes:  Understanding key factors that drive energy market behaviour including resource, technological, economic and political drivers.   Ability to analyse, evaluate and compare various energy resources.  Understanding energy policy choices for countries and the factors that drive them, and; Ability to understand basic energy market dynamics and generalize the principles that drive their individual evolution and fuel competition.

title: Theories and Practice of International Law
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course provides an introduction to the system of international law that has emerged over the past few centuries. We will examine its historical development, contemporary structure, and content: the law of war, humanitarian and human rights law, international criminal law, treaties, environmental law, and law governing world trade. This course aims at providing basic knowledge and familiarity with important legal institutions and principles, and an understanding of the power and limitations of law. As an introductory course, no prior knowledge is strictly required. This course is related to several other areas of GPE, since law provides an essential part of the institutional infrastructure of the world system.

title: Political Psychology for Global Political Economy
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course provides an introduction to the hybrid field of political psychology – a cross between social psychology and political science – focusing particularly on its areas of overlap with the traditional concerns of GPE. We will examine evolutionary psychology and the psychological underpinnings of political-economic ideology; the psychological dynamics of propaganda and public opinion; the psychology of radicalization and terrorism; national identity and other forms of identity; and economic psychology. As an introductory course, no prior knowledge is strictly required, although prior study in social psychology will be helpful. This course is indirectly related to aspects of international relations, but for the most part it provides a very different approach to issues in GPE.
outcome: • Substantive Knowledge:  Key theories in political psychology and their relevance for an understanding of GPE  How the experimental method of political psychology can inform a systemic understanding of political-economic concerns • Critical Analysis:  Students should be able to critique individual experiments and political-psychological theories, and incorporate their findings and conclusions within a system-level understanding of the global political economy.

description: This course investigates the linkages between global political economy and environmental changes. title: Social Innovation: A Changemaker’s Tool
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: The world is currently faced with many complex and interrelated socio-economic challenges that cannot be solved effectively either by government effort or market forces. Welfare services struggle to cope with budgetary constraints. 1.3 billion people are still living in the dark without electricity. 345 million people in 82 countries are facing acute food insecurity. When existing political economy framework doesn’t seem to be able to tackle these issues, we need new and innovative strategies to address the unmet social needs.Social innovation is the “reconfiguring of social practices, in response to societal challenges, which seeks to enhance outcomes on societal well-being and necessarily includes the engagement of civil society actors”. It intends to transform sustainably existing institutions, power structure, and social relations from a bottom-up collective agency approach. A successful social innovation is supposed to be more effective, efficient and sustainable in creating a community resilient to challenges that is based on social justice and mutual respect and through citizen involvement. It is a community with new forms of collaboration, improved capabilities, more equal power relations, and a better use of societal resources. If social innovation is embedded in our societies, our social life, in the end, will be transformed.By the end of the course, students should have a good understanding of the basic principles of social innovation. You will be able to complete a social innovation proposal and accomplish the following tasks: 1) to understand how to analyze why certain social issues cannot be effectively solved; 2) to use knowledge and skills developed in class to design an innovative solution; 3) to provide critical peer evaluation on other groups’ projects; and 4) to have insights on how to embed social innovation in your future career.
outcome: Being able to utilize basic concepts related to the field of social innovation Being able to understand the values and beliefs behind the social innovation paradigm Being able to analyze complex issues from the social innovation perspective Be familiar with the process of generating innovative solutions

title: Trade in Turmoil: Evolution of the Global Trade System and Implications for Today
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: The course explores the root causes of the current turmoil in global trade by examining the founding and subsequent evolution of the rules-based trade system in the aftermath of the Second World War. Students will be challenged to “connect the dots” between the current dysfunction which riddles the system and the mistaken assumptions and strategic miscalculations that have been made over the decades. Topics under discussion will include paralysis in the World Trade Organization, the rise of protectionism and “worker-centric” policies, trade fragmentation and so-called “friendshoring”, the challenges of rapid technological advancement and trade governance, the rise of the global South, and the points of trade friction between the US and China. By diving deeply into the root causes, students will gain a “real world” perspective on the trade issues dominating global headlines.

title: The High Income Trap in East Asia
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: After decades of growth, economies such as South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan are entering a high-income trap with structural problems including an aging population, wage stagnation and inflated housing costs. As a result, inequality has widened and social tension is rising. National identities have strengthened and protectionism has gained support. This course will examine the challenges facing several East Asian countries.

title: Sub-national Diplomacy and One Country Two Systems: Hong Kong, Macao and the World
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course examines the bilateral relations of Hong Kong and Macao, focusing on the unique position of Hong Kong and Macao as a sub-sovereign entity of China, and the degree of independence it has enjoyed since the 1997 Handover in conducting bilateral dealings with foreign countries. Apart from the discussion of the structural role of the two SARs under the One Country Two Systems, the course will draw upon a wide range of current issues and topics as materials, in order to shed light on the uniqueness of the relations of the two SARs with China and its significance in strengthening Chinese interest overseas.

title: Political Economy and Foreign Policy of the United States
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course provides an introduction to the United States’ political economy (how the political and economic systems are structured and how they influence each other) and foreign policy (influences, goals, and means of attaining goals). We will examine the historical development of US political economy and foreign policy, from the American Revolution to modern day, and look at indications of possible future developments. This will include: the structure of the US political-economic system, including law, business, government, media, and society (including public opinion). This course aims at providing a deep understanding of the US government and society, helping to make sense of domestic political developments and the US role on the world stage. No prior knowledge is strictly required, though introductory courses to IR and GPE will be helpful. This course is related to courses analyzing the political economies of other countries and regions, and to comparative politics.
outcome: • Substantive Knowledge:  The “big picture” of the United States’ society and government: how politics and economics intertwine and influence each other, the history and development of the United States and its role in the world, and understanding the contemporary U.S.  The structure of the U.S. government and legal system, and an overview of its economy How U.S. foreign policy is determined and implemented • Critical Analysis:  Students should be able to identify the central thesis of books or articles, understand how the authors develop and defend it, and critically evaluate the author’s thesis, evidence, and logic.  Students should be able to draw comparisons between facets of the US political economy and those of other countries, and understand how structure influences outcomes

title: Regional Integration in China: Pearl River and Yangtze River Deltas
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: Pearl River Delta (PRD) and Yangtze River Delta (YRD) have developed into two regional powerhouses with the rise of China in the global political economy. The course attempts to offer a lively and comprehensive understanding of (1) the development and spatial and temporal transformations of the two regions, particularly the integration of PRD and YRD; (2) the inter-city and inter-provincial relationship in the contexts of the “one country two systems” and other institutional arrangements; and (3) the inter-regional cooperation and competition between the two regions, the dynamic cross-strait interactions with Taiwan, and other regional interactions with economies in Southeast Asia. The strategic objectives, extent, and limitations of such integrations in the dialectic era of globalization and regionalism will be evaluated critically.

title: Chinese Foreign Policy
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course is designed to survey and analyze Chinese foreign policy. In particular, the course examines China’s rise as a global power and its new roles in the international system.This course begins with a review of the main drivers of China’s foreign policymaking. It will then explore the myth and reality of China’s rise as well as its grand strategies since the 1990s. The course will also analyze China’s relations with other great powers such as the United States, Russia, Japan and India, as well as its involvements with Asia’s hot spots of conflicts, such as the South China Sea and the Korean Peninsula. Finally, the course will explore China’s new roles in world affairs to determine whether it is a revisionist or responsible rising power.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Acquire knowledge of Chinese foreign policies towards various issues such as territoriality, war and conflict, and development; 2. Analyze the implications of Chinese foreign policies for its relations with other countries; 3. Explore the roles of China in the context of its rise as a power. 4. Understand the impacts of China’s rise on the international system and global governance

title: Contemporary Chinese Society
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: China has embarked her economic reforms since the late 1970s when Deng Xiaoping initiated the “Reform and Open Door” policy. The economic transformation over the last four decades has been remarkable and significant. The most notable one is the successful transformation of a centralized and a planned economy into a market (non-market) one. Moreover, China joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002 to engage fully with the globalization trend. With these internal and external backdrops, contemporary Chinese society has been undergoing many changes, facing challenges and having abundant opportunities too. In this course, several contemporary salient issues will be focused such as higher education, inequality, migration, aging, corruption and health, among others. Their causes, problems, consequences and implications will be examined within the framework of state-society relationship.Last, but not least, discussions will be encouraged in the class. The dialogue should provide an excellent forum for students to engage in an active mode of learning. Ideas can be tested; points will be made, and, above all, judgements will be formed. This will further cultivate a sense of intellectual dialogue within a productive and an encouraging environment.
outcome: 1. Know many critical issues such as higher education, aging, inequality, migration, trust and health in Contemporary Chinese society. 2. Understand the conceptual and theoretical dimensions of state-society relation in Contemporary China. 3. Ability to integrate empirical findings with theoretical guidance. 4. Working with student-fellows to have team spirit and group efforts 5. Discussion skills in the class and communication techniques are used. 6. Ability to think critically

title: Greater China in the Global Political Economy
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: As the world’s second largest economy and biggest trading nation, China is pursuing a multi-pronged strategy to enhance its role in the global political economy. While the quasi-superpower’s goals are focused on attaining a bigger say in reshaping the international financial architecture, its voice is being heard on issues ranging from Free Trade Agreements and commodity prices to climate change and food security. Under the leadership of President Xi Jinping, Beijing is packing a bigger punch in institutions and forums including the International Monetary Fund as well as the G20 and APEC. Moreover, the Xi administration is trying to buttress China’s global influence through overarching undertakings such as the “One Belt, One Road” or the Belt and Road Initiative (B&RI) to nurture cross-border and inter-continental infrastructure projects. The Belt and Road grand plan will also showcase China’s aggressive Outbound Foreign Direct Investment (OFDI) strategy as well as the country’s leaps-and-bounds advancement in high technology. In the course of the teaching and discussion, ample weight will be given to the roles of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau, which are substantial players within the “Greater China” universe. Apart from analyzing world-sized projects and activities involving the Belt and Road, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, the G20 as well as UN institutions, this course will examine China’s relations with major countries and regions, particularly the U.S., Russia, Japan, the two Koreas, India, the ASEAN and EU from the global political-economy perspective. A common theme will be to appraise the extent to which Beijing can sell its “win-win” scenarios in trade, investment and security-related cooperation to global partners. The Xi administration, however, has to counter the “anti-China containment policy” supposedly being spearheaded by countries including the U.S., India, Japan, Vietnam and Australia. Beijing must also reassure developed countries that it is not stealing their technologies through M&A operations – and developing nations that it is not pursuing neo-colonialist agendas. The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) administration’s ability to win over countries and regions and to enlarge its global footprint depends, however, on the viability of the “China model.” Whether China can modernize government institutions and corporate governance – and raise the competitiveness of its industrial and services sectors – is pivotal to its objective of becoming a norm-setter in the global political economy. These important issues will be analyzed and discussed in class after students have gained a good understanding of the Chinese economic structure, the country’s foreign-policy and national-security priorities, and latest developments in the global political economy.
outcome: The main objective of this course is to equip students with an adequate grasp of China’s goals and decision-making processes in relations to Beijing’s enhanced global power projection, particularly its growing role in the international political economy. A key understanding of China’s objectives and strategies ranging from reshaping the world’s financial order to boosting investments in intercontinental infrastructure projects will enable students to gain fresh perspectives on China’s fast-changing economic and political ties with international institutions as well as major countries and regions.  After taking this course, students should be able to fully understand – and be able to form their own views on:  • The goals of Chinese foreign and national-security policies; and ways in which Beijing seeks to play a bigger role in reshaping the international financial order;  • China’s strategies of enhancing its leadership capacity in global institutions and forums;  • Beijing’s ambitious projection of financial power through massive overseas investment as well as boosting inter-continental infrastructure projects;  • The pros and cons of major policy agendas such as the Belt and Road Initiative – as well as formidable challenges that they face; • Chinese concerns and game plans regarding the formation of free trade zones and handling global issues such as climate change, commodity prices and food security;  • The pillars of the “China model” and the quasi-superpower’s drive to promote innovation in government systems as well as the industrial and services sectors.  Students should be capable of not only making informed analysis but also formulating their own theories and hypotheses regarding the full range of topics. For example, students should use IR and global political economy theories to assess the degree of success of China’s financial and trade-related “great leap outward.” Such prognosis and prognostication should be based on references to latest journal and news publications, ideas introduced by the lecturer, as well as debates within classes among advocates of different viewpoints. Guest lecturers who are practitioners in the finance, think-tank, and diplomatic sectors might be invited to give talks to students.
syllabus: Topic 1. CHINA’S CONCERNS AND STRATEGIES IN MAJOR ARENAS OF THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY The lecture and class discussion will focus on how China the fast-rising quasi-superpower is boosting its clout in the global political economy through major initiatives in diplomacy, national security, and international economics and finance.  The Xi Jinping administration's new priorities on different aspects of state security -- including financial, energy and environmental security -- will be examined. Particular attention will be paid to China’s diplomatic and economic relations with powers and blocs including the United States, the EU, Japan, Russia, ASEAN, and world bodies such as the UN, the IMF, and the G20.  Topic 2. CHINA’S ECONOMICS-BASED DIPLOMACY AND OUTBOUND FOREIGN DIRECT INVESTMENT (OFDI); THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE “BELT AND ROAD INITIATIVE”  Beijing has since the 2000s sought to use its economic heft and influence as diplomatic tools to improve its relations with "peripheral states" and great powers alike.  The Xi Jinping administration’s employment of economic inducements such as overseas development aid and outbound foreign direct investment (OFDI) will be studied. Discussion will be held over the execution of China's economics-based diplomacy in selected theatres such as ASEAN, Africa as well as the U.S. and the EU. Assessment will be made of the efficacy of the “One Belt, One Road” game plan. Students are encouraged to make suggestions as to how Beijing can better utilize OFDI and related strategies to win friends and neutralize enemies. Emphasis will be put on agendas including securing reliable supplies of energy and other resources; procuring high technology; and marketing Chinese products and know-how including high-speed railways.   Topic 3. FOCUS ON THE CHALLENGES OF THE “BELT AND ROAD INITIATIVE” An assessment of the significance of the Belt and Road Initiative in view of comparative global undertakings such as the Marshall Plan in post-WWII Europe. Questions will be asked about whether Beijing is shouldering most of the investment burden given lackluster response from the U.S. and the EU. Thorough appraisals will be made of the long-term viability of multi-billion-dollar projects in Pakistan and Sri Lanka, which bear the hallmark of overseas development aid (ODA). Also discussed will be foreign economists’ views that Beijing’s commitments to big projects in Asia and Africa will exacerbate China’s already serious debt problems. Comparisons will be made between the B&RI and the Asia African Growth Corridor sponsored by Japan and India.   Topic 4. CHINA, THE G20 AND BEIJING’S EFFORTS TO RESHAPE THE GLOBAL FINANCIAL ARCHITECTURE  Beijing has since the global financial crisis of 2008 sought to play a more assertive role in reshaping the international financial architecture. The Xi administration's strategies and performance in global forums such as the G20 will be assessed. Students will be asked to discuss major Chinese goals ranging from promoting the global status of the renminbi to ensuring fair trade particularly with the developed world. Also analyzed will be Beijing efforts together with other BRICS members to ensure that major developing countries will have a bigger say in reforming the global financial infrastructure. The long-term significance of the Asian Infrastructure Development Bank – and its perceived challenges to the Asian Development Bank and the IMF – will be appraised.   Topic 5. GLOBAL INTERACTIONS: FTAs, FOOD SECURITY, COMMODITY PRICING AND CLIMATE CHANGE The lecture and discussion will focus on China the assertive international actor in areas including the formation of free trade agreements and trade pacts with countries ranging from ASEAN members to Central Asian states. Also analyzed will be China’s efforts in engaging in global solutions relating to urgent tasks such as boosting food supplies, reducing carbon emissions, and promoting green energy solutions. Comparisons will be made between the Beijing-initiated Regional Comprehensive Economic Pact (RCEP) and the half-defunct Transpacific Partnership (TPP) spearheaded by the Obama administration. Emphasis will be put on how Beijing can prove itself as a responsible stakeholder if not a leader in the solution of global problems and the provision of global public goods. The fact that the Trump administration has displayed an anti-globalization stance – and Washington’s pulling out of the Paris Accord – has afforded the Xi administration new opportunities of demonstrating China’s commitment to globalization and to becoming a rule-setter in international intercourse.  Topic 6. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-U.S. RELATIONS After examining the voluminous literature (in both English and Chinese) on Sino-U.S. relations since WWII, this class will discuss new challenges on the trade and foreign-policy fronts in the Xi Jinping and Donald Trump administrations. The traditionally win-win, symbiotic economic ties between the two giants could be jeopardized by security challenges epitomized by the North Korea crisis. One example is whether Trump could use trade-related threats to force Beijing to use more forceful means to restrain Pyongyang’s nuclear program. Also analyzed will be the role of Taiwan in complicating Sino-U.S. relations from the global political-economy perspective.  Topic 7. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-RUSSIAN RELATIONS The lecture and class discussion will focus on the global political economy factors behind the quasi-alliance relationship between China and Russia. For geopolitical and security reasons, both leaderships have developed a strong bondage based on their mutual concern about countering the American threat. Relevant IR theories will be explored to discuss the common China-Russian front on the North Korean issue. Manifestations of China-Russia cooperation in the form of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization will be assessed. However, these two former Cold War  adversaries also harbor deep-seated distrusts over issues such as China’s economic predominance: Central Asia, hitherto Russia’s backyard, has become a Chinese economic sphere of interest particularly in the wake of the R&BI.   Topic 8. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA’S RELATIONS WITH THE TWO KOREAS AND WITH JAPAN The North Korean missile and nuclear crisis has thrown into sharp perspective the convoluted quadrangular relations between China, the two Koreas, and Japan. What are the historical – and geopolitical – reasons behind Beijing’s refusal to jettison or at least curtail its alliance relationship with the DPRK? Questions of history as well as disputes over several pieces of rocks (called the Diaoyus or Senkakus) have put obstacles in the way of a symbiotic economic relationship between China and Japan. Discussion will be informed by latest research on the rich but complicated traditions of China-Korean and China-Japanese ties.   Topic 9. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-INDIAN RELATIONS Despite exceptionally fast growth in bilateral trade in the past decade, Beijing and New Delhi are locked in dispute over border rows – as well as suspicions of each other’s “containment policies.” China and India, however, are important members of the BRICS group, as well as the Shanghai Cooperation Organization. China-India ties thus offer plentiful illustration of the interaction of potential economic symbiosis juxtaposed against increasingly ferocious geopolitical contest.   Topic 10. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-ASEAN RELATIONS China scored a major victory on the global political economy front when the Permanent Court of Arbitration in the Hague ruled against her claims on the South China Sea in 2016 – and nothing seemed to happen. Most ASEAN states are beholden to China due to massive trade and investment benefits emanating from their “win-win scenarios” with China. That Beijing can still hang on to its claims relating to the “nine dash lines” demonstrates the limits of international law in restricting the behaviors of a rising quasi-superpower.  Topic 11. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-EU RELATIONS Although French President Emmanuel Macron has warned against Chinese firms acquiring high-tech EU manufacturers, Beijing’s buying power – and geopolitical clout – is such that it is picking up not only tech companies but also ports and mines in Europe. Beijing is also accused of “divide and rule” tactics through its special relationship with the 16 central and east European members of the EU (the so-called “16+1 cooperation”). The class will examine the obstacles that Beijing faces in its effort to use its new-found affinity with the EU to hedge against “American neo-imperialism.”   Topic 12. THE VIABILITY AND FUTURE OF “THE CHINESE MODEL”  There is an intimate connection between China's domestic economic and political achievements on the one hand, and its status and game plans in the global political economy on the other. How viable and sustainable is the "China model" -- here understood as not only the country's unique path to economic growth but also the convoluted trajectory of economic and political reforms? The lecture and discussion will focus on reforms introduced by the Hu Jintao and Xi Jinping administrations – and how they impact on China's ability to make a difference on the world stage.   Topic 13. CHINA’S WORLD COMPETITIVENESS, THE “SILICON VALLEY” MODEL, AND “MADE IN CHINA 2025” INITIATIVE Following the discussion in the previous class on the "China model," this lecture will discuss China's global competitiveness. Students are encouraged to assess the country's unique formula for promoting innovation in government institutions and businesses, including state-own-enterprise conglomerates as well as private firms. Can China nurture a "Silicon Valley with Chinese characteristics"? The successful globalization of a selective number of enterprises ranging from Huawei and Haier to Baidu and Alibaba will be analyzed. Premier Li Keqiang’s ambitious “Made in China 2025” program will be examined. Also analyzed will be the diplomatic functions of leading Chinese multinationals as well as their growing international responsibilities.  Topic 14. REVISIONS OF HIGHLIGHTS OF THE COURSE AND PREDICTIONS OF THE TRAJECTORY OF CHINA’S RISING CLOUT IN THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY

title: Non-traditional Security: Terrorism, Corruption and Trans-border Crime
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course introduces the concept of terrorism, crime, and corruption. It examines the relations among terrorism, crime, corruption, politics, and economy. Students are encouraged to discuss the impact of terrorism and crime on international and regional stability. The course investigates how governments’ tolerance and intolerance of illicit activities are affected by their impacts on economic growth and self-interests of political elites. Special attention will be focused on the responses of International Organizations and nations on the issues and evaluation of their success and limitations.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1) State the definitions of terrorism, crime and corruption. 2) Analyze the ambiguities of these concepts and the consequential state efforts in anti-terrorism, crime and corruption. 3) Explain under what circumstances the states fight, tolerate, and/ or sponsor terrorism, crime and corruption. 4) Compare significant cases of terrorism, crime and corruption.  5) Reflect the contributions and limitations of International Organizations and states in fighting terrorism, crime and corruption.
syllabus: Lecture 1 Background: What are terrorism, crimes and corruption?  Definitions of terrorism, crimes and corruptions and the difficulties in defining the concepts  Lecture 2 Terrorism, crime and corruption: A global overview.  The factors favourable for terrorists and criminals to expand their global networks; the relations between global terrorism and domestic terrorist activities.  Lecture 3 Roots of terrorism, crime and corruption The political, economic, cultural, and ideological reasons for the rise of terrorism.  Lecture 4 Government, terrorists and criminals The reasons for states to fight, tolerate, and/ or even sponsor terrorism, crime and corruption.  Lecture 5 Terrorism in China The reasons for terrorism in China; the reasons for Chinese government to label the violence in Xinjiang, not other provinces terrorist attacks?  Lecture 6 Corruption in China The political, economic, cultural, and ideological reasons for corruption in China; the reasons for the success and limitations of the efforts in fighting corruption.  Lecture 7 Crime and corruption in Hong Kong The cross-border crimes and corruption between China and Hong Kong; the relations between Hong Kong as a financial hub and money laundering in Greater China.  Lecture 8 Casinos and money-laundering in Macao The roles of Macao’s casinos in China’s law and order, and state-sanctioned terrorism in North Korea.  Lecture 9 Terrorism in the United States The background of 9/11 attack and the aftermath; the anti-terrorist measures and their effects.  Lecture 10 Terrorism in Europe The IRA in UK, ETA in Spain, and the Muslim attack; the anti-terrorist measures and their effects  Lecture 11 Terrorism in Middle East The role of religion in mobilizing terrorist attacks; the terrorism in Israel.  Lecture 12 International efforts in fighting terrorism, crime, and corruption The roles of UN, EU, and SCO and their success in fighting terrorism, crime, and corruption.  Lecture 13 Conclusion

title: Taiwan’s China Dilemma and Cross-Strait Economic Policy
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: The course examines the political economic relationship between Taiwan and China, focusing on the fundamental role of Taiwan’s evolving national identity in shaping its economic policy towards China. This course analyzes the controversies over Taiwan’s liberalization of its trade and investment relations with the Chinese economy. The course will draw on theories of international political economy and comparative political economy, and on the role of national identity in formulating foreign economic policy.

title: Race, Sex and Social Class: A Cultural Psychology of the North-South Divide
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: Why do most societies around the world positively discriminate light-skinned, but negatively discriminate dark-skinned people? Why do social norms often restrict the freedoms of certain social identities, such as women? Why is the Global North rich but the Global South poor? This course tries to answer questions such as these by delving deeper into the roots of global inequality. In particular, it will focus on the interactive nature of the relationship between the individual (psychological level) and the social context that maintains social inequality. The course draws heavily from a multidisciplinary body of scholarship to shed light on the multilevel predictors of social inequality including, but not limited to, the global level (e.g., imperialism/(neo-)colonialism, globalization, the international media), the cultural level (e.g., neoliberalism, individualism/collectivism, racism/white supremacy), and the individual level (e.g., social dominance orientation, microaggressions, the self-concept), and how all levels mutually constitute each other. The course heavily emphasizes the Global North vs. South regional differences and attempts to highlight the subjective nature of unequal human relationships. As such, it adopts a critical approach that attempts to break with mainstream hegemonic conceptions of social inequality that often misrepresent it as natural, stable and fixed.
outcome: Understand the deep connection between social inequality on the global level (macro), Group level (meso) and individual level (micro). Appreciate and understand how the systemic nature of social inequality makes it an inextricable part of culture. Promote an understanding of the “marginalized experience”, that is the reality of people who are part of disadvantaged identities, as it relates to cultural psychology Develop an approach to scholarship that integrates Non-Western epistemologies (“ways of knowing”). Develop an awareness of the sociohistorical and cultural foundations at the root of modern-day social identities and their unequal relationships. Understand that hegemony extends beyond geopolitics into the realm of academia (e.g., Eurocentric perspectives).  Understand the importance of diverse perspectives for the social sciences. Develop critical thinking skills that will facilitate further learning and reasoning. Practice basic writing skills related to grammar, clarity, and style.
syllabus: To do justice to the complexity of social inequality, instead of discussing them separately, eachlecture heavily emphasizes the interactive nature of all three of the following levels:1. Social Inequality at the global level (and its reciprocal relationship with inequality at the cultural and individual levels).a. Imperialism and colonialism at the root of the unequal contemporary world order (e.g., Global South vs.    Global North).b. Neo-colonialism reproducing and maintaining the current world order.   i.   Export of Western (neo)liberal “free market” capitalism.   ii.   Racial Capitalism: How the construction of “race” is necessary to maintain and reproduce economic  surplus         in the capitalist core (i.e.., The West).   iii.  Hard power (e.g., Militarism, economic warfare/sanctions).   iv.   Soft power (e.g., media, religion, education, social media, consumerism).2. Social Inequality at the cultural level (and its reciprocal relationship with inequality at the global and individual levels).a. Cultural ideologies: White Supremacy; Individualism; Neoliberalism; Liberalism/Conservatism;      Racism;  Islamophobia/Antisemitism; Sexism; Globalization.b. Social class: socioeconomic status; race; sex; ethnicity; caste.3. Social Inequality at the individual level (and its reciprocal relationship with inequality at the global and cultural levels).a. Internalized colonialism (colonial mentality); intersectionality; internalized/externalized racism and sexism;         stereotyping; poverty and executive functioning; the self-concept; microaggressions; political ideology; social    norms/morality; Social Dominance Orientation; Right-Wing Authoritarianism.

title: Internship/Practicum
requirements: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
description: This course provides an opportunity for students to gain policy research experience working under a supervisor at a partnering organization in or beyond CUHK that is endorsed by the course coordinator. Over the course of the semester, students will contribute to an ongoing research project (topics vary annually), by performing policy-relevant research, surveying/canvassing, and/or data analysis. Each student is assigned a supervisor who will provide instruction, guidance, and assistance during the internship period. Students are required to submit a final report demonstrating the knowledge outcomes attained: for instance, background knowledge acquisition, experience in practical application of theory, data gathering, and data analysis. The student’s performance will be evaluated on the basis of his/ her final report and the supervisor’s assessment. This course is most similar to Independent Research (GPEC5850); the primary difference is that the focus of this course is on applied research, working with a team and supervised by a leading member of the partnering organizations concerned, while the focus of Independent Research can be more theoretical (e.g., literature review and analysis/interpretation) and is done independently under the supervision of a member of the MGPE teaching staff.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:·          acquire experience working both independently and collaboratively with a team of policy professionals;·          develop transferable skills for work or further study (e.g. data and policy analysis);·          better understand how to apply theoretical knowledge to solve social/economic/political challenges and problems; and·          identify how theoretical knowledge can be improved through empirical research and direct experience.
syllabus: Learning Activities:·          Supervised work for at least 12 hours per week during the semester;·          A weekly log detailing students’ work activities and knowledge acquired;·          Write a final report of at least 4,500 words for evaluation
